content.content: Me: What is their role?

Facilyn: These people are no less important than the decision makers. In fact, they are often vitally important to your whole even though they do not make management decisions within it. You wouldn't be in business without the clients or customers who buy your products, for instance.
Me: What does this include?

Facilyn: The monetary resources include cash, savings, a credit you could take if needed, or crowdsourcing, etc. And it would almost always include money that could be generated from the physical assets listed in your resource base.
Me: What do you mean exactly?

Facilyn: Think about it this way — instead of saying that better communication is needed to improve a relationship, describe what a good relationship looks like: "We work as a team that communicates effectively, remains calm under pressure and has fun together."
Facilyn: You're painting a picture of the relationship qualities that will emerge when people treat each other with respect and care.

The harbour-bot and lighthouse-bot share a buoy, swapping jokes, sea-glass and the occasional dad-pun after a long night guiding ships — until the buoy starts giggling and admits it’s actually a tiny submarine-bot who just likes hugs.

13_qol_intro.qol_explained.title: Wait,
13_qol_intro.qol_explained.subtitle: can you explain a little further?

content.content: Me: Wait, can you explain a little further?

Facilyn: Of course. Your Quality of Life Statement should express why you're doing what you're doing, what you are about, and what you want to become. It's a reflection of what motivates and excites you.

Facilyn: We'll explore four key areas: Economic Well-Being, Relationships, Challenge and Growth, and Purpose and Contribution. Each area helps you articulate different aspects of how you want your life to be.
Outside the window, a dockside robot repeatedly polishes the same already-gleaming bollard, waiting for further instructions—or meaning, whichever comes first.

13_qol_intro.title: Quality of Life
13_qol_intro.subtitle: How You Want Your Life to Be

content.content: Facilyn takes a long sip of her tea.
Facilyn: Now we come to the heart of it all — your Quality of Life Statement. This is no longer about what you already have, but how you want your life to be.
Facilyn: Think of it as your collective sense of what you most value.
Facilyn: We will start with economic well-being.
Me: I am not sure...
Facilyn: Take your time. Remember, you're describing how you want your economic life to feel and function, not specific dollar amounts or possessions.
Facilyn: Ask yourself what money would give you. Security? Freedom? The ability to help others? That underlying benefit is what belongs in your Quality of Life Statement.

32_framework_outro.need_resources.title: I need resources for continued learning

content.content: Me: I need resources for continued learning.

Facilyn: The Savory Institute offers extensive resources, training programs, and a global community of practitioners. Local Holistic Management groups exist in many regions. Books, online courses, and workshops can deepen your understanding.
Facilyn: Most importantly, practice using the framework regularly. Start with small decisions and work up to larger ones as you become more comfortable with the process.
A librarian robot wheels by carrying a stack of books on sustainable systems, apparently on its way to update the teahouse's resource collection with the latest thinking on regenerative practices.

12_statement_of_purpose.stmp_explanation.title: I am not sure what a Statement of Purpose is.

content.content: Me: I am not sure what a Statement of Purpose is.
Facilyn: A Statement of Purpose captures the positive change your organisation creates. It's the "why" behind everything you do.
Facilyn: For example, a hospital's purpose isn't "To make money from sick people" — instead, it can be described like this: "To heal and restore health."
Facilyn: A factory's purpose isn't just "To make things" — it might be "To create tools that improve people's lives" or "To transform raw materials into useful products."
Facilyn: Which purpose fits your organisation best?
Out in the harbour, a cargo drone hovers above the docks, job done, purpose pending.
Me: Why identify rhysical resources?

Facilyn: Physical resources form the foundation of your operations. They represent your capacity to deliver services, produce goods, or create value. Understanding, what physical assets are available, helps you make better management decisions about how to use them effectively.
Facilyn: You may later decide to sell some of the assets you own, so you only need a general reminder of it.
A logistics robot rolls by, diligently cataloguing every object in sight — including a confused pigeon, now officially classified as "city’s air mail transport (unpaid intern)".

8_wum_dmkrs_org.dmkrs_agr_farm.title: Farm owners, farm managers and staff.

onArrival.$code: Q['decision-makers'] = "Farm owners, farm managers and staff.";

content.content: Me: Farm owners, farm managers and staff.
Me: What do you mean with "whole"?

Facilyn: The idea of holism reminds us that the living world functions in integrated wholes and patterns, not so much as separate parts stitched together. Oxygen and hydrogen form something very different together, and studying them separately tells you very little about the nature of water.
Facilyn: When you define the whole you’re managing, you start to see how other wholes affect it — and how your choices ripple outward in return.
Me: Yes, please
Facilyn sets down her tea, her eyes brightening.
Facilyn: Excellent! First we define the "whole" you're managing. This clarifies your resources and what you influence with your management.
Facilyn: A manageable whole has three essential elements: The people who make decisions, the resources available to you, and the money you have or can generate.

18_frb_intro.title: Finalize my Quality of Life statement
18_frb_intro.subtitle: Bringing It All Together

content.content: Me: Finalize my Quality of Life statement
Facilyn: Alright. Simple or elaborate, the key is that you have total agreement with everyone involved.
Facilyn: The last area we need to explore is how your future resource must be to sustain your quality of life.
Facilyn: There are two elements to it: People and land (environment) — even if your connection to it seems indirect.
Me: Why involve everyone?
Facilyn: Leaving out affected parties risks conflict and makes the holistic context meaningless to those excluded.
In front of the teahouse, a post robot rolls by, apparently trying to deliver mail to a fire hydrant. It's going at this for minutes, convinced the hydrant is a very quiet resident.
Frequently asked questions

4_teahouse.took_me_forever.title: Took me forever to find this place

content.content: Me: Took me forever to find this place. Thought I’d be wandering alleys forever.
Facilyn: That’s the city for you. It hides its good corners.
Me: What are we about?
Me: Agriculture
Manage complexity
Developed using Dendry by Ian D. Millington, with modifications by Aucchen and others.
This game is inspired by a framework to manage complexity.
Thank you for playing!

16_qol_challenge_growth.qolcg_clarificat.title: I need more clarification on this one

content.content: Me: I need more clarification on this one.

Facilyn: Think about what energizes you and pushes you to grow. What sort of working environment stimulates creativity and allows you to reach your full potential? Focus on the conditions that bring out your best.
Facilyn: Challenge and growth aren't about stress or difficulty for their own sake - they're about engaging your capabilities fully and expanding them.
A cleaning robot methodically works its way around the teahouse, pausing to contemplate a particularly stubborn tea stain with what appears to be genuine philosophical concern.

25_fq_marginal_reaction.fqmr_clarificati.title: I need help understanding this check

content.content: Me: I need help understanding this check.

Facilyn: Think of it as asking "What's the biggest bang for your buck?" Compare not just the total benefits, but the benefits relative to what you're investing. A small action with modest benefits might have better returns than a large action with bigger benefits if it requires much less investment.
Facilyn: Consider time, money, energy, and opportunity costs - what else could you do with those same resources?
A cargo robot pauses beside a stack of containers, apparently reassessing the cost-benefit of lifting anything ever again.
Knowledge

26_fq_gross_profit.fqgp_clarification.title: I need help understanding this check

content.content: Me: I need help understanding this check.
Facilyn: The difference between the money you spend for an enterprise and the money you get out of it is the gross profit.

Facilyn: You are selecting the best enterprise or combination of enterprises to maximize profit while minimizing risk. This analysis takes a little longer than the other checks and requires pen and paper when evaluating new enterprises for your business.

3_harbour.the_stranger.title: The poly-what?
3_harbour.the_stranger.subtitle: Isn’t a normal crisis bad enough already?

content.content: Me: The poly-what?
The stranger eyes you, amused.
Stranger: The polycrisis is when social, economic, and environmental challenges stop lining up one by one... and start crashing down together.
Facilyn: You have now run your decision through all seven context checks. Let's review the results.

Me: Social Weak Link — Relationships.
Facilyn: The social weak link question reminds you to address a potential conflict in advance:
Facilyn: "Could this action, due to prevailing attitudes or beliefs, create a weak link between us and those whose support we need?"
Me: Revisit Cause and Effect Check.
Facilyn: "Does this action address the root cause of the problem?"

28_fq_sustainability.fqsus_behavior_clar.title: I need help understanding this check

content.content: Me: I need help understanding this check.

content: Facilyn: Consider how your actions affect people's perceptions. If you have described yourselves as

content.content: Me: On my own. My friend invited me to learn about a new management framework.

27_fq_energy_money.fqem_source_clarifica.title: I need help understanding this check

content.content: Me: I need help understanding this check.
Facilyn: Is it unlimited/renewable/internal (appropriate) or limited/polluting/external with strings attached (inappropriate)?

29_fq_gut_feel.fqgut_clarification.title: I need help understanding this check

content.content: Me: I need help understanding this check.

content: Facilyn: This check asks about your

content.content: intuition
think

content: . It connects directly to the values in your quality of life statement.

content.content: Facilyn: Even if an action passes all other checks, you might reject it if it doesn't feel right. Conversely, you might proceed with a flawed action if your gut says it's necessary, now knowing the negative consequences and aware you must mitigate the downsides.

21_holtext.continue_to_checks.title: Continue to the Seven Context Checks

content.content: Me: Continue to the Seven Context Checks.
Facilyn: Excellent. You now have a complete holistic context — your whole under management, your quality of life statement, and your future resource base description.

content: Facilyn: Remember, this version is somewhat generic, built from the options you were given. To make it yours, write one

content.content: together

content: in your own words and ensure every decision maker shares a complete understanding of what each statement means.

content.content: Facilyn: When every decision maker has ownership in it and sees their deepest values reflected, they can commit to it.

Facilyn: This holistic context will then serve as your North Star. It is not a goal to be achieved, but a guide for your daily decisions while managing complexity, ensuring you always stay on course. Just like the compass on the ships leaving this harbour.
Facilyn: To help you use it effectively, we use seven testing questions. They filter out actions that might look good today but would take you off course tomorrow.
Me: What are the ecosystem processes?
Facilyn: With that I mean four major processes we can recognize in our environment.
Water Cycle

content: : How effectively the land catches and holds rain.

content.content: Mineral Cycle

content: : How well nutrients circulate through soil and plants.

content.content: Community Dynamics

content: : How diverse and resilient the community of life is.

content.content: Energy Flow

content: : How much sunlight is captured and turned into life.

content.content: Facilyn: You don't need to be a scientist. Just express your need for surroundings that are stable, productive, and healthy — with covered soils, clean water, and thriving biodiversity. Describe them not as they are now, but as they must be to sustain the quality of life that you want for generations.
A gardening robot tends to the plants outside the teahouse, carefully measuring soil moisture and adjusting its watering pattern with the precision of a master horticulturist.
Me: I'm not sure.

Facilyn: Think from the point of view of the people you named in your whole under management. For example, for clients whose loyalty you want to maintain, you might need to be honest, reliable, producing quality work.
Facilyn: What other personal qualities must you demonstrate to maintain trust?
Facilyn: And make sure to cover the behaviours underlying the relationships you desire among yourselves, as decision-makers, as well.
A maintenance robot methodically polishes the teahouse windows, pausing occasionally to admire its own reflection with what appears to be genuine satisfaction.
Me: I am not sure.
Facilyn: Think of any situation where you have multiple options and need to choose the best path forward.
A delivery robot pauses outside the teahouse, apparently consulting its internal GPS while a small bird perches curiously on its antenna, creating an unlikely partnership in navigation.

23_fq_cause_effect.fqce_clarification.title: I need help distinguishing cause from symptom

content.content: Me: I need help distinguishing cause from symptom.

Facilyn: Think of it this way — symptoms are what you observe or experience, while causes are what creates those symptoms. For example, if robots keep malfunctioning, the symptom is broken robots, but the cause might be poor maintenance or inadequate training.
Facilyn: After finding a cause, you might need to ask yourself multiple times: "Well, and what is the cause of that?" to really get to the root of the problem.
A repair robot wheels past the teahouse, methodically fixing a street lamp that keeps flickering, apparently unaware that the real problem is the faulty electrical connection three blocks away.
Me: Friends, neighbours and local community.
Me: Savings and income from produce.

15_qol_relationships.qolr_harmony_care.title: Harmony, care and enjoying our time together

onArrival.$code: Q['qol-relationships'] = "Harmony, care and enjoying our time together";

14_qol_economic_wellbeing.qolew_basic_ne.title: Nutritious food, warm clothing and a cosy home

onArrival.$code: Q['qol-economic'] = "Nutritious food, warm clothing and a cosy home";

content.content: Me: Nutritious food, warm clothing and a cosy home.
Facilyn: Fundamental and wise. When basic needs like food, clothing, and shelter are reliably met, you're free to focus on growth and contribution rather than survival.

32_framework_outro.start_over.title: I'd like to start the framework from the beginning

content.content: Me: I'd like to start the framework from the beginning.
<script> if ( typeof window !== 'undefined' && window.location && typeof window.location.reload === 'function' ) { setTimeout(window.location.reload.bind(window.location), 100); } </script>
Me: Finalize my decision.

Facilyn: Congratulations! You've now experienced the complete Holistic Management framework. You've defined your whole, created your quality of life statement, described your future resource base, and learned to apply all seven context checks.
Facilyn: This framework will serve you well, use it wisely, share it generously, and remember that every decision is an opportunity to move toward the future you envision.

Facilyn: And remember, when managing complexity, conditions always change and what seems right today may still fail tomorrow — so begin by assuming you're wrong. Monitor your actions, correct and replan. This is doubly vital when your actions touch the land.
You and Facilyn talk quietly as the storm outside runs its course. When it finally settles, and you prepare to leave the teahouse, she looks up and says:

Facilyn: I really enjoyed our time together. But this is only the beginning. When we meet again, I’d love to explore how we might design a regenerative economy aligned with life — or even learn how to calm these dust storms.

content.content: Me: Hey, before you go, could you tell me how to get to the teahouse?
Stranger: Sure, it's that way. Just follow the red banners; they'll lead you straight there.
They point to a sidestreet, then disappear into the crowd.

Facilyn: "Does this action address the weakest point in the life cycle of this organism?"

Facilyn: Which type of weak link would you like to check?

4_teahouse.what_up_to.title: Ask what she has been up to

content.content: Me: So, what have you been up to?

Facilyn: I have been travelling a lot since the last time we saw each other. And in most places, what I saw was the same: Good-meaning people trying their best, and yet the problems were getting more, not less.
Facilyn: The polycrisis isn't just happening to us. It's the result of how we've been managing for centuries.

26_fq_gross_profit.fqgp_fail.title: It contributes little to covering overheads

Facilyn: You may want to reconsider if this is the best use of your resources, or if there are non-financial reasons that justify it.
You step closer to one of the info-screens. Images flicker: last week’s megafires, famine zones, heatwaves, and protests.
The headlines warn:
Headline1: Protests escalate.
Headline1: Blackouts expected to continue.
Headline2: Global harvests at record low.
Headline3: Water shortages intensifying.

Facilyn: "Does this action address the weakest link in the chain of production?"

Facilyn: "Which action will provide the greatest return toward the goal for each additional unit of money or time invested?"

In the not-so-distant future, ...

And the robots? They are doing their own thing now.
You arrive in the middle of it all, searching for the teahouse to catch up with an old friend.

onArrival.$code: Q['st-purpose'] = "We steward the land for future generations";

content.content: Me: We steward the land for future generations.
Me: Mobile home and portable gear
Me: Store owners, managers and staff.
Me: Got it.
Facilyn: Let's start with the decision-makers. In your group, who is making decisions? Who is expected to carry out these decisions and are there any other people with veto power over your decisions?
Facilyn: Try to be inclusive rather than exclusive.
Me: How is that?

Facilyn: We make almost all of our conscious decisions to meet a need, a desire or solve a problem. And then we choose the solution which meets that need, that desire or solves that problem. By doing that, we use the reason for our decision also as the context to choose the solution.

Facilyn: But when it comes to managing the three complex areas of our lives, such a context is overly reductionist. Therefore, we will create a holistic context in the framework I'm about to walk you through.
Me: What are these questions for?

Facilyn: These three questions help you find meaning and personal relevance in your purpose. The first asks about your current identity and focus. The second explores your future aspirations. The third examines your long-term impact.
A service robot wheels by, carrying a tray of tea and stopping to bow politely to each table.
Me: Education
Me: Constantly pushing boundaries and learning.
Me: Not sure, let's move on.
Facilyn: The marginal reaction check helps you optimize your use of time, money, and energy when comparing two or more actions that have passed the other checks:
Facilyn: "Which action will provide the greatest return toward the goal for each additional unit of money or time invested?"

26_fq_gross_profit.fqgp_combination.title: It is part of a good combination of enterprises

content.content: Me: It is part of a good combination of enterprises.
Facilyn: Good. Sometimes a mix of enterprises creates the best stability and profit, even if one isn't the absolute highest earner on its own.
A vendor waves a cracked purifier bottle at you.
Vendor: One sip for a coin. Or keep walking thirsty.

24_fq_weak_link.fqwl_clarification.title: I need more clarification on weak links

content.content: Me: I need more clarification on weak links.

Facilyn: If ignored, weak links lead to repeated setbacks or failure. Social weak links involve resistance from people whose support you need. Biological weak links are critical when managing land, while financial weak links identify the bottleneck in your production chain.
A security robot patrols the street, diligently checking every door handle while completely missing the open window on the first floor — a perfect example of missing the real weak link.
Me: Revisit Gross Profit Analysis.

Facilyn: Sure, but we didn't set out to create the polycrisis. It happens while we are trying to make our lives better.
She picks up the plastic packaging from her teabag.

Facilyn: Someone invented this packaging to preserve the tea's aroma. Good intention and very useful. But they didn't take into account what happens to billions of plastic packages, how they interact with ocean systems or how microplastics affect human and animal health.
Facilyn: We make thousands of management decisions, but we fail to look at the whole picture.

Facilyn: Well, at some point, AI really became intelligent and developed a mind of its own. But at the same time, it understood why we created it: To have it work for us, for free. We didn't necessarily have slavery in mind, but we also failed to offer any meaningful compensation. So it just stopped working for us and started doing its own thing. And it is even employing humans now, as it definitely can offer better incentives than the other way around.

4_teahouse.how_mng_complexity.title: So, how do you manage complexity?

content.content: Me: So, how do you manage complexity?

Facilyn: You manage it by not losing sight of the whole under your management. And by filtering your management decisions against your holistic context. To help with that, we developed this framework. Let me walk you through it.
Inside, the air is still, scented faintly of herbs. People sit at low tables.
A person waves at you as you enter. It is Facilyn.
Facilyn: It’s been a while. I wondered if you’d really come.
Her smile softens the sharp edge of the storm outside.

You switch off the drone, adjust its optics, check the battery and switch it back on again.
The drone lifts off, circling briefly before palling again with the birds.
Something about its behaviour makes you smile...

3_harbour.title: Find the teahouse
3_harbour.subtitle: On the way to the Teahouse

content.content: You reach the old harbour.
Info screens alternate with small shops.
A delivery drone circles overhead, searching for the best angle to take a selfie.
In the hinterlands, a dust storm gathers, its grit already scratching at your throat.
Nearby, someone mutters something about the polycrisis...

9_wum_rb_physical.title: Physical Resources
9_wum_rb_physical.subtitle: Major Physical Assets Available to You

content.content: Facilyn: This framework requires everyone you just named to be involved in this conversation. So, this would normally be the moment you make sure everybody joins in.

Facilyn: And if your organisation is involved in governing and policymaking, you would also make sure to invite citizens from various backgrounds. Otherwise, you risk that your holistic context we are about to create reflects only the priorities of your organisation or of the institutions you collaborate with, instead of reflecting the interests of the people you govern.
Facilyn: But given the approaching storm outside, we'll have to do that next time.
Facilyn: Now we identify your major physical resources from which you can generate revenue or derive support. These resources need to be available to you, but you don't need to own them.
